p: Reston ebolavirus was first discovered in 1989 from laboratory macaques exported from the Philippines to the USA [ 36, 37]. Subsequent detections of the same virus were made in primates in 1992 and 1996 [ 38], and Reston ebolavirus was found to be circulating in pigs in the Philippines in 2008 [ 39]. A small percentage of people (1% of 458 exposed individuals) from the 1989 and 1996 events were found to have IgG antibodies to Reston ebolavirus, but were asymptomatic [ 38]. Reston ebolavirus infection in humans is rare and not known to cause any human disease.
